titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Frederick Albert Pottle Papers
titlestmt.author: compiled by Diane E. Kaplan and Bella Z. Berson

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Thursday January 10, 2019 at 10:54

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: The papers include correspondence, teaching materials, and writings that document Frederick Pottle's scholarly interest in English literature, primarily the work of James Boswell. The papers also reflect Pottle's involvement in the affairs of the Yale English Department, Colby College, and the Episcopal Church.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright status for collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Frederick Albert Pottle Papers (MS 1605). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The correspondence, teaching materials, and writings in the Frederick Albert Pottle Papers focus primarily on Pottle's scholarly interests and to a lesser extent on his personal life. Although the earliest material dates from the nineteenth century, the papers are concentrated in the period of Pottle's teaching at Yale, ca. 1928-1970. Pottle's contributions to the study of James Boswell are evident throughout the papers, though his responsibilities as head of the Yale Editions of the Private Papers of James Boswell are not reflected in them.

The papers also document Pottle's involvement in several endeavors outside of Yale University. Pottle's religious commitment to the Episcopal Church is highlighted in the files for his work on the Joint Commission on Holy Matrimony, for the General Theological Seminary, and for his church and diocese. Pottle's devotion to his alma mater, Colby College, is evident in his files as a trustee and in the many speeches and lectures he gave there. Pottle's army service during World War I and his continuing involvement with the members of Evacuation Hospital #8 are reflected in his correspondence and writings.

The papers are organized in series by record format, but certain types of material can be found in more than one series. For instance, general correspondence with publishers is arranged in Series I, but correspondence concerning a particular title is in Series III.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Frederick Albert Pottle, the foremost scholar of James Boswell, was born in Center Lowell, Maine, on August 3, 1897. He received his B.A. from Colby College in 1917, served in an Army evacuation hospital from 1917 to 1919, and then entered Yale University, earning his M.A. in 1921, and his Ph.D. in 1925. He became a full professor at Yale in 1930 and was named Sterling Professor of English in 1944. His work on Boswell commenced with his doctoral dissertation. After Yale acquired the rare Boswell manuscripts in 1949, Pottle became editor-in-chief of the Yale Editions of the Private Papers of James Boswell, serving in this capacity until 1979. Additionally, he wrote a multi-volume biography of Boswell. During his tenure at Yale, Pottle was chairman of the English Department and director of graduate studies. He also served as a trustee of Colby College and the General Theological Seminary. He married Marion Isobel Starbird, on September 9, 1920. They had three children, Annette who died young, Christopher and Samuel. Pottle died on May 16, 1987.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged in four series: I: Correspondence, 1914-1978. II: Teaching Files, 1922-1966. III: Writing and Research Files, 1913-1979. IV: Personal Files, 1861-1974.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Pottle's correspondence is mainly with colleagues, students, publishers, professional societies, and religious groups. There is relatively little correspondence with Pottle family members and with Pottle's sister, Nellie Hankin, and her family. The files contain both incoming and outgoing correspondence.

The bulk of the correspondence, which dates from the 1920s to the 1970s, is arranged alphabetically by individual or corporate name. When there are few letters from a single correspondent, these have been grouped with others having the same initial letter. Following Pottle's own arrangement, correspondence for the years 1971-1979 is filed by year. There is some overlap between the alphabetical and chronological files for the early 1970s.

did.unittitle: Episcopal Church. Joint Commission on Holy Matrimony
Committee to Advise the President on the Appointment of a Director for the Beinecke Library
English Department Committee on a Major Appointment

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains lectures, notes, assignments, bibliographies, and examinations for courses Pottle taught at Yale. There is also one folder of similar materials associated with Pottle's teaching at New Hampshire State College. The lectures included in this series were in Pottle's files of course related materials. The material is arranged, as Pottle filed it, by course numbers. The university changed these course designations over the years, the titles of the courses were rewritten, and the same course number can have two different titles. For example, The Age of Wordsworth was also given as The Romantic Poets, but not always with the same course number. Pottle taught this course over many years and it contains the are the largest number of folders in the series. Since specialized courses often contained some of the same subjects taught in a more general course, occasionally, there are lectures filed with one course though the lecture originated in another course. At the end of this series, there are some course- related materials without a clear indication of the particular course with which they were associated.

did.unittitle: English 48/150, English Poets of the Nineteenth Century
English 150, The Romantic Movement/The Age of Wordsworth
English 150, The Romantic Movement/The Age of Wordsworth

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series includes articles, lectures, book reviews, introductions, short stories, and poems written by Pottle, as well as background research files. The writings are arranged in chronological order. Writings lacking dates are arranged alphabetically by title after the dated material. A partial bibliography of Pottle's writings is available in Series IV. The file for an individual title may contain correspondence, notes, reviews, and drafts for unpublished works. Reprints for published papers are generally not included. The articles and lectures relate to literary topics and also to religious subjects. Many of Pottle's talks at Davenport College, Yale University, and also at Christ Church, New Haven, are documented here, as is the book, Stretchers, which records Pottle's World War I experience. The series concludes with one folder of book reviews by Pottle and background files containing research notes and correspondence arranged by topic.

did.unittitle: Ronaldson's collection of original poems by Scottish Gentlemen

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains biographical material, partial bibliographies of Pottle's writings, loose clippings and scrapbooks of writings by and about Pottle, and memorabilia. A few student notebooks, class papers, and lists of accessions to Pottle's library are also included. The series incorporates books, articles, and letters associated with Reverend James Gammack, who was rector emeritus at St. James Church, West Hartford, Connecticut at the time of his death in 1923. These were probably the gift of Pottle's friend, John Wilson Gammack. The photographs include portraits of Pottle and pictures of his family, friends, and associates.
